AllRequestData.Job-Description: Join the Discovery Center team for a day in this once-a-year opportunity to see what happens behind the scenes to keep an exhibit looking its very best. Projects may include: washing rocks, painting, organizing consumable materials, repairing a faux beaver's lodge, or laminating children's literature.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: No particular skills required.  %0AFeast on donuts (AM) or cookies (PM).
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Wear your dirty clothes (no joke) and sneakers.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist in cleaning the many real objects in the Discovery Center.%0AAssist in installing new exhibit components.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist Collections Department with various duties such as moving artifacts in storage or on exhibit, data entry, research, preventive conservation, or storage area organization.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Must be willing and able to follow specific verbal and written directions, climb ladders, use basic hand tools, and lift 30 lbs.
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Wear comfortable clothes in which you can climb, bend, and kneel.  Closed toe shoes are recommended.  PPE will be provided as necessary.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Moving artifacts.%0AConducting artifact or exhibit history research.%0AEntering data in database or spreadsheet.%0AAssisting with artifact cleaning.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Learn about the exciting world of Traveling Programs by participating in an on-site visit to a local school, library, or camp. GSEs will begin their day by meeting a TP educator at the crack of dawn in the Museum garage, helping load the van in the morning, riding along in a very colorful Museum van through Boston traffic, and checking-in at a local educational institution. Once the educator has finished setting up the program, GSEs can expect to serve as a spectator during the assembly or workshop program, as they witness the ins-and-outs of outreach education first-hand. (Note: Half-day shifts can sometimes run up to 4.25 hours. Full-day shifts are usually around 6 hours.)
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: None--driving and teaching will be done by our staff.
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Comfortable casual clothing and Museum badge.

AllRequestData.Job-Title: Nat Geo Live/Lynsey Addario production asst
AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist with production of "National Geographic Live: A Photographer's Life of Love and War" with Lynsey Addario on Sunday, Oct 28 at3:00pm in Cahners Theater. Hear hair-raising stories and see amazing photos by this Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist who has covered war zones around the globe and survived being kidnapped in Iraq and in Libya.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Specific training provided the week before the program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Attend training in Gordon Wing.%0AHelp answer questions in MOS lobby..%0AHelp direct visitors to Cahners Theater.%0AHand out program notes and welcome people as they enter the theater.%0AAssist LSP team with Book Signing in Cahners after program.%0AHelp LSP team wrap up and bring supplies to our pod in Gordon East.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: You will spend a full day on the Charles River Clean-Up Boat, patrolling the river for floating trash and debris and plucking it from the water. The boat will have one captain and up to 2 (Two) volunteers. The Charles River Clean Up Boat is a privately funded, 501 (c)(3), non-profit organization whose objective is to remove the floating trash from the Charles River. The Clean Up Boat has removed several hundred bags of trash since 2007, greatly improving the water quality and appearance of the Charles River for everyone, including our MoS visitors. For more information and to sign up for a shift on the Clean Up Boat please visit www.cleanupboat.org. You must sign up on the clean Up Boat website *before* signing up for the GSE. Please note that not all GSE dates will be available due to other Volunteer signups.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: None.
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Life Jacket, you can bring your own or one will be provided to you. Dress for being outdoors. It is suggested that you bring a hat, sunglasses, sun block, and rain gear (if any risk of showers).%0A
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Patrolling for and cleaning up trash found in the Charles River.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist the Marketing department with the annual College Night event, where 4000+ students in the Boston area can attend Exhibit Halls without charge. Duties will include checking student I.D.s and providing them buttons for admission, overseeing an laptop email signup station, assisting with live presentations and more.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Should be comfortable engaging with college students, providing them with some information and answering standard questions they may have.
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Comfortable clothing and shoes (lots of standing). Ability to interact with large crowds.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: - Assist with checking college I.D.s%0A- Hand out buttons and programs to college students.%0A- Oversee email signup.%0A- Assist with live presentations%0A- Help students (4000+ in attendance) with any questions or concerns.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Hi all, we're recruiting conversation facilitators for our Journey To Mars forum, which takes place on the evening of October 8.  Facilitators will participate in a training, attend the forum, and guide the discussion using materials and methods we created through a collaborative project with NASA.  We have already recruited these facilitators, so please do not sign up for this GSE unless we have talked with you already!
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: We will provide a brief training at the beginning of the GSE experience.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Attend facilitator training and Forum program (in Skyline)%0AFacilitate conversations following a script and brief training that we will provide%0AHelp with other basic duties such as greeting guests as needed.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist and interact with guests throughout a before-hours event. NOTE: Assistance will only be needed until 8:45am.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Professional and courteous, as you would interact with guests during museum hours.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Join educators from the Museum of Science at Fenway Park to facilitate interactive space activities for visitors to the "El Mundo Family Festival" on Sunday, August 26th from 10:30 am to 2:30 pm. Volunteers will meet at Fenway Park for the event, and detailed activity and arrival information will be provided before the event.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Lead educator will train how to run the "soaring satellites" activity on the day of the event.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: - Arrive to Fenway park on own by 10&#58;30 am%0A- Brief training from 10&#58;30-11 am%0A- 11 am to 2 pm help facilitate activity with guests%0A- 2 to 2&#58;30 pm clean-up activity and depart%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Title: Killing Cancer with Cannabis production assistant
AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Killing Cancer with Cannabis on Monday, October 1 at 7:00 p.m., in Cahners Theater. %0A%0ASuccess stories of cannabis curing cancer are not new, but they've often been anecdotal. The precise cannabinoids that kill specific cancer cells have not been identified - until now. David (Dedi) Meiri, PhD, is discovering which combinations of the cannabis compounds are able to destroy which specific cancer types. Find out about Meiri's game-changing research and the promise that medical marijuana may hold in the battle against cancer. Reception to follow.%0A%0AIn conversation with Kara Miller, host and executive editor of WGBH's Innovation Hub

AllRequestData.Job-Title: Fake Science with ImprovBoston production assistant
AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Fake Science with ImprovBoston comedy show on Thursday, October 4 at 7:30 p.m., in the Planetarium. %0A%0AThis fall for one night only, ImprovBoston returns to the Museum of Science for a completely improvised adult comedy show that's out of this world! New England's oldest and biggest comedy theater brings its signature off-the-cuff laughs to the far reaches of the galaxy with the expert technological wizardry of the Planetarium. Immersive science meets immersive comedy as ImprovBoston's professional improvisers create games, scenes, and songs out of thin air using the Planetarium's state-of-the-art projections, surround sound, and 360-degree videos.%0A%0AArt and science collide in a supernova of gut laughs - and you have a front row seat. For ImprovBoston and the Museum of Science, all the universe is a stage!

AllRequestData.Job-Title: The Big Quiz Thing production assistant
AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for The Big Quiz Thing on Tuesday, October 9 at 7:30 p.m., in the Planetarium. %0A%0AThe Big Quiz Thing returns, bringing its multimedia quiz-show spectacular to the Charles Hayden Planetarium! Hosted by Quizmaster Wes Hazard, the Big Quiz Thing is more than a bar trivia event: it's a full team-based game show, with video and audio puzzles, the Lightning Round, the Buzzertastic Finale, and the best, most 'figureoutable' trivia questions anywhere. And it's all played via the BQT's unique digital answer system (play on your smartphone or another digital device).%0A%0APlus, there's hope for the non-geeky: Smart-Ass Points for wrong but funny answers. All for honor, glory, and prizes. Learn more about the Big Quiz Thing at BigQuizThing.com.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Walter Sickert and the Army of Broken Toys Halloween Happening on Thursday, October 25 at 7:30 p.m., in the Planetarium. Walter Sickert and the Army of Broken Toys return to the Museum of Science for one night only! Kick off your Halloween as the Toys take over the Charles Hayden Planetarium for an unforgettable evening of masquerade, music, and mayhem under the dome. Beware, they're not alone - other tricks and treats lurk around every corner of the Toys' macabre Museum!
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 5:30pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby, hand out guest list tickets, answer questions, explain adult programs and brochure sign up, and direct people to Planetarium.%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 7&#58;30pm show (or 9pm show if the 7&#58;30pm sells out!)%0A

JobTitle: Walter Sickert and the Army of Broken Toys Halloween Happening production assistant

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Our (Super)Human Brains on Wednesday, November 14 at 7:00 p.m., in Cahners Theater. %0A%0AIf you could experience someone else's feelings, imagine what you could do with that superpower. If you could get your body to metabolize dessert as if it were a diet food, think of how you could exercise that superpower. Treat yourself to an unusual excursion into the world of a doctor who uses his (super)synesthetic brain to treat patients, and learn about the secrets of your own (super)human brain. Book signing to follow.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 5:00pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby, hand out guest list tickets, answer questions, explain adult programs and brochure sign up, and direct people to Cahners.%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 7&#58;00pm program.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Every September, all Salem residents can attend the museum for FREE thanks to a generous gift from the Read Family Trust. This includes a free, round-trip ride on the commuter rail this Saturday, 9/22. Join the advancement team as we travel out to Salem to assist residents in getting their free passes, maps, trip planners, and find their way to the museum from North Station.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Walking, standing
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: Casual dress, please wear comfortable shoes and your museum badge
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Help hand out train vouchers, maps, trip planners, and postcards to residents. Explain to them the process and how to redeem tickets, answer any general museum questions.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Hi,%0A%0AThese people will act as table observers for an all-day forum we are hosting on Saturday in collaboration with Arizona State University. Your job will be to take notes on the facilitated conversations during the day using a short template we will provide.  You do not need to know anything about the topic to be a table observer.  We can give you a laptop to use or you can use your own device. We will provide you with breakfast and lunch.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: You will need to complete an online human subjects training course in advance.  %0A%0AThere will be a short 10-minute conversation right before the program begins to go over any last logistics.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Listen and record conversations at round tables.%0AWe will provide you with questions to help you take notes.%0ATake notes on a laptop computer (we can provide one).%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: The 2018 Washburn Award will honor Margot Lee Shetterly, the author of Hidden Figures: The American Dream and the Untold Story of the Black Women Who Helped Win the Space Race. We will be welcoming 200 guests and the evening will feature a VIP reception, general reception, dinner, and awards presentation, featuring remarks by Ms. Shetterly and a brief Q&A.%0A%0AYou will have the opportunity to assist with wayfinding, registration, and other duties as needed. Those staying past 7:00pm will be provided with dinner.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: All necessary information will be provided the week prior to the event.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist with guest check in%0ADirect guests to different areas of the Museum%0AHelp manage a Q&A%0AOther responsibilities as needed%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Gifts to the Annual Fund support every aspect of the Museum's daily operations. And we appreciate every contribution, both big and small!%0A%0AHelp us give thanks to our lower level supporters by helping us in folding and assembling our 'Thank You Mailers'

AllRequestData.Job-Description: This GSE is a half day Butterfly Garden helper, which will aid the BG staff in watching over the exhibit's living collection, educating the visitors in related topics, and ensuring USDA containment is met.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Must have knowledge of butterfly biology and understanding of USDA containment basics.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Help educating visitors, watching out for the needs of the living residents, and making sure USDA containment is met.
AllRequestData.Historical-Admin-Notes: November 20, 2018 9:17 am - Lorah Broderick - Hi Leah, I'm going to go ahead and approve this job as a one time exception. GSEs are meant to be open to all staff and cannot be targeted toward one employee or a specific group of employees. For business need so you don't have to shut down the Butterfly Garden, you can have this GSE. In the future please just schedule this employee to work this shift as a part of their job.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Hi all, we're recruiting conversation facilitators for our Defending Planet Earth from Asteroids forum, which takes place on the evening of November 27.  Facilitators will participate in a brief training, attend the forum, and guide the discussion using materials and methods we created through a collaborative project with NASA.  This should be a fun forum, we'd love to have you help us!
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: We will provide a brief training at the beginning of the GSE experience.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Attend facilitator training (in Hodgkinson) and Forum program (in d'arbeloff)%0AFacilitate conversations following a script and brief training that we will provide before the Forum event%0AHelp with other basic duties such as greeting guests as needed.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Help greet visitors in "All Aboard!  Trains at Science Park!" Your primary role is to be available in the gallery to provide guest service, answer questions from visitors, and address concerns that may arise.  You might also explore the exhibit and help visitors make observations as you feel comfortable.  We'll schedule a short 15 min orientation to prep you for your time in there.  During the orientation, we will give you a quick overview of the exhibit, including very basic background info and an FAQ tip sheet.  We will also review procedures and provide contact information for addressing common problems.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: You will be standing or strolling for most of the shift.  Wear comfortable shoes!
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: A red lab coat or apron will be provided for you.  Skirts must be longer than a lab coat; no shorts please.  Wear shoes that you will be comfortable standing and walking in for the duration of your shift.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: â¢ Schedule a 15 minute orientation with Interpretation staff prior to or at the beginning of your shift.  %0Aâ¢ Review the tip sheet provided prior to your shift%0Aâ¢ During your shift, monitor the exhibit and answer visitor questions

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist Interpretation staff in providing hands-on learning experiences for Museum visitors in the Hands-On Laboratory.  Depending on your own areas of comfort, you might help greet visitors as they come in, assist visitors at activity stations, and/or help with basic cleanup and maintenance of activity materials. %0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: We will try to arrange a time for you to come by to observe a program before your scheduled shift.  We will also arrange for someone to give you a quick orientation to the lab at or before the start of your shift.  You will have a chance to try activities yourself before helping visitors.  %0A
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: You will be provided with a Museum lab coat.  Please wear close-toed shoes that are comfortable for standing.%0A
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: -schedule a 15 minute orientation to the lab at or before the beginning of your shift%0A-greet visitors in a warm and friendly manner%0A-answer general questions about the Museum%0A-assist visitors with activities and engage them in conversation as you are comfortable

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for National Geographic Live: When Women Ruled the World on Friday, January 11 at 8:00 p.m., in Cahners Theater. %0A%0AThroughout history, powerful women have been called many things â witches, regents, and seductresses. But there was a time in the ancient world when at least one was called King. Dr. Kara Cooney, professor of Egyptology, explores the reigns of powerful ancient queens to illuminate a time when women ruled the world. Often neglected in the history books, these strong female leaders were considered exceptions to the rule, but their power and influence are undeniable.%0A%0AAs the global leader in visually compelling storytelling, National Geographic engages and enlightens curious audiences, and empowers them to make a difference in the world. The Museum of Science and World Music/CRASHarts partner to bring two premier events in the highly acclaimed speaker series National Geographic Live.%0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 6:30pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby%0AHand out guest list tickets%0AAnswer questions%0AExplain adult programs and brochure sign up%0ADirect people to Cahners.%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 8:00pm program.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Boston Science Fiction Film Festival on Tuesday, February 12  at 7:30 p.m., in the Planetarium. %0A%0AJoin the Boston Science Fiction Film Festival and the Museum of Science for an exclusive preview screening of the exciting new documentary Wizards of Hollywood, under the dome of the Charles Hayden Planetarium! %0A%0AThey pioneered the CGI, Special Effects that make the Marvel Universe and modern filmmaking possible.  Now their story will be told in this new documentaryâ but thereâs more. The film is not finished, but you are invited to a work in progress event to preview 75% of the movie, followed by a discussion between the audience and the director about what works and what doesnât. Donât miss your chance to have a direct impact on the making of this anticipated new documentary! With special guest Ed Kramer, Director of Wizards of Hollywood and Industrial Light & Magic alum.%0A%0AThe Boston Science Fiction Film Festival (âBoston SciFiâ) is an 11-day cinematic event held at the historic Somerville Theatre from February 8th to the 18th. The 2019 edition marks the 44th anniversary as the longest running genre fest in America. For more information visit bostonscifi.com. %0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 6:00pm on day of program.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Heartbreakers & Heartthrobs: A Drag King Valentine's Day Under the Dome on Thursday, February 14  at 7:30 p.m., in the Planetarium. %0A%0ABring Out the Boys! Get ready for a truly unique and delicious evening of entertainment as the Slaughterhouse Society and friends invade the Planetarium for a super romantic drag king event! Enjoy as our kings give you a Valentineâs Day to remember, accompanied by innovative and immersive, cutting-edge visuals overhead on the full dome. After the massive success of the Society's show as part of the Summer Thursdays series, they team up with the Museum of Science again to delight audiences with an out of this world, one night only, genderbent experience! The candles are lit, the rose petals are aplenty, and all that we need to make the night perfect... Is you. Come early to enjoy a cash bar and complimentary light snacks before the show, starting at 6:30pm in the Planetarium lobby!%0A%0AThis program is for audiences 18+.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Fake Science w/ ImprovBoston in the Planetarium. %0A%0AThis Winter/Spring, ImprovBoston returns to the Museum of Science for a completely improvised adult comedy show that's out of this world! New England's oldest and biggest comedy theater brings its signature off-the-cuff laughs to the far reaches of the galaxy with the expert technological wizardry of the Planetarium. Immersive science meets immersive comedy as ImprovBoston's professional improvisers create games, scenes, and songs out of thin air using the Planetarium's state-of-the-art projections, surround sound and 360-degree videos.%0A%0AArt and science collide in a never-before-seen supernova of gut laughsâ¦ and you have a front row seat. For ImprovBoston and the Museum of Science, all the universe is a stage!%0A%0AFake Science with ImprovBoston is for audiences 18+.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Doubling Down: preserving Our Humanity in the Digital Age at 7:00 p.m., in Cahners Theater. %0A%0AAre the big digital technology companies actually modifying our behavior? Will that be the means to a beneficial end? We are inside a global-scale experiment in data-gathering about human behavior.  We have devices on us all the time. The devices give us real time feedback about our actions and provide that information to companies that are vying for our attention. Is this model of our society sustainable? Is it contributing to the demise of democracy occurring before our very eyes?%0A%0AJoin Jaron Lanier, the âfather of VR,â bestselling author Sue Halpern, and physicist Marcelo Gleiser to talk about doubling down on being human, a step that just might rescue our world â and ourselves.%0A%0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 6:00pm on day of program.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for ReelAbilities Film Festival presents Intelligent Lives in Cahners Theater.%0A%0AFrom award-winning filmmaker Dan Habib comes Intelligent Lives, a catalyst to transform the label of intellectual disability from a life sentence of isolation into a life of possibility for the most systematically segregated people in America.%0A%0AIntelligent Lives stars three pioneering young American adults with intellectual disabilities â Micah, Naieer, and Naomie â who challenge perceptions of intelligence as they navigate high school, college, and the workforce. Academy Award-winning actor and narrator Chris Cooper contextualizes the lives of these central characters through the emotional personal story of his son Jesse, as the film unpacks the shameful and ongoing track record of intelligence testing in the U.S.%0A%0AJoin us for the closing night celebration of the 2019 festival including a special conversation and Q&A with special guests.  Reception with light bites to follow. ReelAbilities Film Festival is dedicated to promoting awareness and appreciation of the lives, stories and artistic expression of people with different disabilities from a variety of communities.%0A

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Synesthesia Suite in the Planetarium. %0A%0ASynesthetic orchestral composer Mary Bichner returns to the Charles Hayden Planetarium, in partnership with the Museum of Science, Boston and The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Arizona State University for a new evening of Synesthesia Suite.%0A%0ADonât miss this one-night only immersive musical experience, featuring live performances of Bichner's compositions paired with stunning visuals directly inspired by her polymodal synesthesia, allowing audience members to âhearâ color and âseeâ sound just as Bichner does when she listens to music. %0A%0AThe synesthetic visuals for this latest concert in the series will be presented in two exciting and innovate forms: a collection of dazzling 360Â° videos created by the Museum of Science's award-winning artistic team for the planetarium's full dome, and an entirely new immersive LED-based technology featuring wearables being developed especially for the concert series by the renowned scientists of MIT Media Lab and ASU's SciHub, as well as generative immersive visuals inspired by nature and physics. Entitled the HyLighter, this new technology will be created under the direction of theoretical physicists Frank Wilczek (Nobel laureate and Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics), and Nathan Newman (Lamonte H. Lawrence Professor in Solid State Science).%0A%0AThe next edition of "Synesthesia Suite" will take place on April 4th 2019, featuring the premiere of the prototype for the HyLighter; and a future concert featuring an even more advanced version of the technology will be scheduled for some time in the Fall/Winter of 2019.%0A%0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 6:00pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby%0AHand out guest list tickets%0AAnswer questions%0AExplain adult programs and brochure sign up%0ADirect people to Planetarium.%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 7:30pm show (or 9pm if the first sells out)

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for the screening of Never-Ending Man: Hayao Miyazaki in Cahners Theater.%0A%0AIn 2013, film director and animator Hayao Miyazaki suddenly announced his retirement at the age of 72. But he couldnât shake his burning desire to create. After an encounter with young CGI animators, Miyazaki embarked on a new endeavor, his first project ever to utilize CGI. But the artist, who had been adamant about hand-drawn animation, confronted many challenges. The film even faces the danger of being cancelled. Can an old master who thinks heâs past his prime shine once again? This program goes behind the scenes over two years as Miyazaki overcomes struggles to create his short film using CGI.%0A%0AJoin us for a one-night only screening of this incredible, intimate look into the process of a cinematic legend.%0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 5:30pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby%0AHand out guest list tickets%0AAnswer questions%0AExplain adult programs and brochure sign up%0ADirect people to Cahners%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 7:00pm screening

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist on production and logistics for Teaching Time to Walk: An Evening with palaver Strings and Nate Tucker in the Planetarium. %0A%0AJoin Palaver Strings and musician and composer Nate Tucker, for an evening of reimagined classics and new compositions under the full dome of the Charles Hayden Planetarium. %0A%0AWhen we play music live, time becomes our medium. Our relationship to time is ever-changing and rich in metaphor; in the words of Paul Celan, âWe shell time and teach it to walk: then time returns to the shell.â  Sometimes we play with audience expectations and sense of stability, while other times we must confine our own personal expression to a âpulseâ that is larger than us. With this program, Palaver Strings invite listeners to think about stability and flux, how we âgo with the flowâ and how we can disrupt it. This program features a collaborative new commission by percussionist, electronic musician, and composer Nate Tucker.%0A
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided at Reg Table in Lobby at 6:00pm on day of program.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Assist at Registration Table in lobby%0AHand out guest list tickets%0AAnswer questions%0AExplain adult programs and brochure sign up%0ADirect people to Planetarium.%0AHelp LSP staff pack up and return easels, signs, etc to Gordon East%0AEnjoy the 7:30pm show

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Help greet visitors in "Wild Kratts: Ocean Adventure!" Your primary role is to be available in the gallery to provide guest service, answer questions from visitors, and address concerns that may arise. You might also help visitors explore the exhibit and make observations as you feel comfortable. We'll schedule a short 15 min orientation to prep you for your time in there. During the orientation, we will give you a quick overview of the exhibit, including very basic background info and an FAQ tip sheet. We will also review procedures and provide contact information for addressing common problems.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: You will be standing or strolling most of the shift.  Wear comfortable shoes!
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: â¢ Clothing and shoes must be in good condition.%0Aâ¢ MOS badge must be worn above the waist at all times.%0Aâ¢ A red lab coat or apron will be provided for you. Skirts must be longer than a lab coat; no shorts please. Wear shoes that you will be comfortable standing and walking in for the duration of your shift.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: â¢ Schedule a 15 minute orientation with Interpretation staff prior to or at the beginning of your shift. %0Aâ¢ Review the tip sheet provided prior to your shift%0Aâ¢ During your shift, monitor the exhibit, assist with stroller parking, and answer visitor questions

AllRequestData.Job-Description: It's Pi Day!  We will be running a variety of math-oriented activities around the exhibit halls and could use extra help supporting guests with various activities. AllRequestData.Job-Description: You will spend a full day on the Charles River Clean-Up Boat, patrolling the river for floating trash and debris and plucking it from the water. The boat will have one captain and up to 2 (Two) volunteers. The Charles River Clean Up Boat is a privately funded, 501 (c)(3), non-profit organization whose objective is to remove the floating trash from the Charles River. The Clean Up Boat has removed several hundred bags of trash since 2007, greatly improving the water quality and appearance of the Charles River for everyone, including our MOS visitors. For more information and to sign up for a shift on the Clean Up Boat please visit www.cleanupboat.org. You must sign up on the clean Up Boat website *before* signing up for the GSE. Please note that not all GSE dates will be available due to other non Museum volunteers signing up simultaneously.%0AIf you signed for a shift on cleanupboat.org and notice that there is no corresponding GSE sign up, please let me know.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: None
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: â¢	Clothing and shoes must be in good condition.%0Aâ¢	MOS badge must be worn above the waist at all times.%0Aâ¢	Life Jacket, you can bring your own or one will be provided to you. Dress for being outdoors. It is suggested that you bring a hat, sunglasses, sun block, and rain gear (if any risk of showers).%0A
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Patrolling for and cleaning up trash found in the Charles River.

AllRequestData.Job-Description: Assist the Traveling Programs team in handing out water/Gatorade to runners along the Boston Marathon racecourse.
AllRequestData.Training-Requirements: Training provided onsite by Boston Marathon volunteers.%0A%0AAll participants must have per-registered  with the Boston Athletic Association as an official Marathon volunteer.
AllRequestData.Dress-Requirements: The event is rain or shine so dress appropriately. Wear layers and have some waterproof clothing/ shoes to keep from getting wet and cold. Having lightweight gloves is a good idea.
AllRequestData.Job-Duties: Fill cups with water or Gatorade and stack them on tables in preparation for the runners. During the race, pas out the fluids to passing runners. After the race, clean up your station and the stretch of street we are posted to so that it is free of trash and debris.
